choices.text: Chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia

questions.text: A G2P1 at 17 weeks presented to the OPD with a BP of 148/90 mmHg. Six hours later, her BP is 142/90 mmHg. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic HTN

 

In pregnancy, the timing of hypertension onset is critical in determining the diagnosis. Chronic hypertension is defined as high blood pressure that is present before pregnancy or that is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation. This patient's blood pressure readings of 148/90 mmHg and 142/90 mmHg at 17 weeks of gestation indicate hypertension occurring before the 20-week threshold, fitting the definition of chronic hypertension.

 

To confirm chronic hypertension, if the patient's blood pressure remains elevated 12 weeks postpartum, the diagnosis is solidified.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preeclampsia: This is incorrect because preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension that develops after 20 weeks of gestation and is accompanied by proteinuria. This patient's hypertension was noted before 20 weeks and there is no mention of proteinuria.

 

Option B. Gestational HTN: This option is incorrect as gestational hypertension also develops after 20 weeks of gestation. This patient's hypertension was detected at 17 weeks, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia: This is incorrect because superimposed preeclampsia would require evidence of new-onset proteinuria or worsening hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation in a patient with pre-existing chronic hypertension. There is no mention of proteinuria in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertension diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation in a pregnant woman is most likely chronic hypertension.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target cell: Target cell can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the postsplenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: Gaucher cell is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme..

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells: Sickle cells are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells, with their distinctive cytoplasmic projections, are a hallmark of Hairy Cell Leukemia, a chronic B-cell malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following compound(s) is most likely to cause diabetic cataract:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of sorbitol

 

Explanation

 

In diabetes, high levels of glucose in the lens of the eye can lead to increased production of sorbitol via the aldose reductase pathway. Sorbitol, being osmotically active, cannot easily cross cell membranes and thus accumulates in the lens, leading to an osmotic imbalance that causes swelling, opacification, and eventually, cataract formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Accumulation of Galactose + Glucose: While accumulation of galactose can lead to cataract formation (as seen in classic galactosemia), in the context of diabetes, the primary issue is the accumulation of sorbitol derived from glucose. Galactose is not typically elevated in diabetic patients unless there is a concurrent metabolic disorder affecting galactose metabolism.

 

Option C. Accumulation of Galactitol + Glucose: Similar to option B, while galactitol (formed from galactose) can contribute to cataract formation in conditions like galactosemia, it is not the primary concern in diabetic cataract where the key issue is sorbitol accumulation from glucose.

 

Option D. Accumulation of Glucose Only: While hyperglycemia (high glucose levels) is the underlying cause of diabetic complications, including cataracts, it's the metabolic conversion of this excess glucose to sorbitol in the lens that primarily contributes to cataract formation, not the accumulation of glucose alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Diabetes mellitus, in the lens by polyol pathway, glucose converted to sorbitol by the enzyme Aldose reductase. Excess Glucose can enter the lens of the eye and get converted to Sorbitol with the help of aldose reductase. This enzyme is a major contributor to diabetic complication due to accumulation of sorbitol which is hygroscopic sugar and causes swelling of the eye in untreated diabetic patients
  • In galactosemia, Dulcitol or Galactitol is responsible for cataract.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 200

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibitor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

PCSK-9 inhibitors are a class of drugs that significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels by inhibiting the protein PCSK-9, which in turn increases the number of LDL receptors available to clear LDL cholesterol from the blood.

 

There are only 2 PCSK-9 inhibitors: Evolocumab and alirocumab. Among the options provided:

 

Evolocumab is a well-known PCSK-9 inhibitor used in modern clinical practice to manage hyperlipidemia, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk of cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is an NPC1L1 transport inhibitor, also known as an intestinal cholesterol absorption inhibitor. It reduces blood cholesterol by decreasing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a newer drug that acts as an ANGPTL3 inhibitor. It is specifically approved for use in patients with familial homozygous type 2 hyperlipidemia.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and an immunosuppressive drug used primarily in organ transplantation and certain types of cancer. It is not related to the treatment of dyslipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels, particularly in high-risk patients.

choices.text: Combined oral contraceptives: 2 tablets within 24 hours and 2 tablets beyond 72 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not recommended as an emergency contraceptive method? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Combined oral contraceptives: 2 tablets within 24 hours and 2 tablets beyond 72 hours

 

Emergency contraception with combined oral contraceptives should be used withing 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. 2 tablets are used within 72 hours and 2 tablets after 24 hours. Using the tablet beyond 72 hours is unlikely to give protection from pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ulipristal 30 mg single tablet: This is an appropriate emergency contraceptive method.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single tablet: This is also a widely recognized and recommended emergency contraceptive method.

 

Option D. Intrauterine contraceptive device insertion: Insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD) is an effective form of emergency contraception if done within five days after unprotected intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency contraception with combined oral contraceptives is not effective if used beyond 72 hours after unprotected intercourse, whereas other methods like ulipristal, levonorgestrel, and IUD insertion are recommended and effective within their respective time frames.

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formication

 

Formication, characterized by the feeling of insects moving beneath the skin, is a notable occurrence in cases of cocaine abuse. This phenomenon is also commonly denoted as Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs.

 

COCAINE

 

  • Derived from the plant, Erythroxylum coca
  • Sigmund Freud studied its pharmacological effects and probably had an addiction to cocaine too.
  • Was initially used as a local anaesthetic (as it blocks fast sodium channels), especially for ENT surgeries.
  • Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine receptors (dopamine & NE reuptake is inhibited) resulting in-
    • Vasoconstriction: HTN, MI
    • Nasal septal perforation (nasal inhalation of cocaine results in nasal congestion and long-term use can cause nasal septal perforation)
    • Seizures
    • Jet black pigmentation of tongue
  • Routes of administration - Snorting (inhalation of finely powdered form into the nose), freebasing (smoking), I.V. and subcutaneous.

 

Intoxication

 

  • Euphoria
  • Sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis)
  • Paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) + auditory hallucinations
  • Tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state is a dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness

 

Option C. Dipsomania is a historical term describing a medical condition involving an uncontrollable craving for alcohol or drugs.

 

Option D. Carphologia is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the trauma center after RTA with shortness of breath. The supine CXR is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemothorax

 

The provided supine chest X-ray (CXR) shows a generalized opacity throughout the left hemithorax, which is characteristic of a hemothorax. In a trauma setting, chest X-rays are often taken in the supine position because the patient cannot stand. In this position, the fluid from a hemothorax gravitates and spreads out across the thoracic cavity, leading to a uniform opacity on the affected side.

 

Hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space, often occurs due to trauma and presents with symptoms of shortness of breath. The key radiographic feature on a supine CXR is the diffuse opacity without a typical meniscus sign, which is seen in erect chest X-rays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: This condition presents with hyperlucency (increased radiolucency) in the affected hemithorax. In a supine CXR, a deep sulcus sign might be seen, but there is no hyperlucency present in the image, ruling out pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Pulmonary contusion: Pulmonary contusions appear as localized areas of consolidation. They do not typically cause uniform opacity throughout an entire hemithorax as seen in this image.

 

Option D. Diaphragm injury: Diaphragm injuries can result in the presence of bowel loops within the thoracic cavity, which is not evident in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a supine chest X-ray of a trauma patient, a hemothorax presents as a diffuse opacity throughout the affected hemithorax due to the gravitational spread of blood in the pleural space.

questions.text: A 60-year-old presents with chronic dacryocystitis. What should be the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dacryocystorhinostomy

 

In a 60-year-old patient presenting with chronic dacryocystitis, the treatment of choice is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR). Chronic dacryocystitis involves the inflammation and obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct, leading to persistent tearing and infection. In adults, this condition typically requires surgical intervention to create a new drainage pathway.

 

DCR surgery involves creating a passage between the lacrimal sac and the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. This bypasses the blocked nasolacrimal duct and allows tears to drain directly into the nose. The procedure effectively resolves the symptoms and prevents recurrent infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lacrimal sac massage: This is typically recommended for congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction in infants, not for chronic dacryocystitis in adults.

 

Option B. Syringing: This procedure can help to diagnose the site of obstruction and may be used in cases of acute dacryocystitis or in infants, but it is not a definitive treatment for chronic dacryocystitis in adults.

 

Option D. Probing: This is also more commonly used in infants with congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. In adults, especially those with chronic inflammation, probing alone is usually insufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis in adults, involving the creation of a new drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the middle meatus of the nasal cavity to bypass the blocked nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: Which of the following solid organ transplants have the highest chance of GVHD (graft versus host disease)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intestine

 

Explanation

 

Graft versus host disease (GVHD) is most commonly associated with hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, particularly allogeneic transplants. However, GVHD can also occur following solid organ transplants.

 

GVHD occurs when donor immune cells attack the recipient's tissues.

 

The intestine has the highest risk of GVHD among solid organ transplants due to the presence of abundant lymphoid tissue, including Peyer's patches, which contain many donor lymphocytes capable of attacking the recipient’s body.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Kidney: While kidney transplants can result in immune complications, the risk of GVHD is significantly lower compared to intestinal transplants.

 

Option B. Liver: The liver has a moderate risk of GVHD but not as high as the intestine.

 

Option D. Heart: The heart has a lower risk of GVHD compared to the intestine.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The intestine is the solid organ transplant with the highest risk of graft versus host disease due to the presence of lymphoid tissue containing donor lymphocytes.

questions.text: DNA-Protein interactions can be studied by using: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA footprinting

 

  • DNA footprinting is a technique used to study DNA-protein interactions. It involves the selective cleavage or modification of DNA sequences by a DNA-binding protein. By analyzing the resulting pattern of cleavage or modification, researchers can determine which regions of the DNA are bound by the protein, effectively "footprinting" its interaction sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA fingerprinting: DNA fingerprinting is a technique used to identify individuals based on their unique DNA patterns, primarily in the context of forensic science and paternity testing. It is not specifically used to study DNA-protein interactions.

 

Option C. Northern Blotting: Northern blotting is a molecular biology technique used to study gene expression by analyzing the presence and quantity of specific RNA molecules in a sample. It is not primarily used to study DNA-protein interactions but rather RNA-related processes.

 

Option D. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): ELISA is an immunological assay used to detect the presence of specific antibodies or antigens in a sample. While it can indirectly provide information about protein-protein interactions, it is not a direct method for studying DNA-protein interactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA footprinting is the appropriate method for studying DNA-Protein interactions, as it allows researchers to identify the specific binding sites of proteins on DNA by selectively cleaving or modifying the DNA sequence. This technique is fundamental for understanding how proteins interact with DNA in various biological processes.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 451

questions.text: The sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pituitary gland

 

Sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the options given above except the pituitary gland. The pituitary does not play a direct role in iodide transport or thyroid hormone synthesis, hence the absence of NIS.

 

The sodium/iodide cotransporter, also known as the sodium/iodide symporter (NIS) is a transmembrane glycoprotein, which transports two sodium cations (Na+) for each iodide anion (I−) into the cell. NIS mediated uptake of iodide into follicular cells of the thyroid gland is the first step in the synthesis of thyroid hormone.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Thyroid gland: The primary site of NIS expression, essential for thyroid hormone production.

 

Option B. Placenta: NIS is expressed to transport iodide to the fetus, crucial for fetal development.

 

Option D. Salivary gland: NIS facilitates iodide transport, although its precise role here is less clear.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The sodium iodide symporter (NIS) is essential for iodide transport in various tissues. The NIS seen in:

 

  • Thyroid
  • Salivary glands
  • Gastric mucosa
  • Placenta
  • Ciliary body of the eye
  • Choroid plexus
  • Mammary glands
  • Certain cancers are derived from these tissues.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which nerve is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Musculocutaneous nerve

 

  • The clinical vignette presented in a patient with difficulty flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, as well as loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm, is suggestive of musculocutaneous nerve injury.
  • One of the most common causes of humerus fractures is a fall from a great height on an outstretched hand.

 

Musculocutaneous Nerve:

 

It is a branch of the brachial plexus, it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in the arm.

 

Muscles Innervated: Supplies the brachialis, biceps brachii, and coracobrachialis muscles.

 

Sensory Distribution: Sends sensory fibers as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, providing sensation to the lateral (radial) aspect of the forearm.

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm due to affected biceps. Loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median Nerve: It arises from the brachial plexus and enters the forearm between the two heads of the pronator teres.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Primarily supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and thenar muscles in the hand.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the lateral (radial) three and a half fingers and the corresponding palm area.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of flexion of the wrist, loss of flexion of lateral fingers, and loss of thumb opposition. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve: It also originates from the brachial plexus and travels posteriorly in the arm.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the triceps brachii and the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the back of the arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand on the radial side.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: "Wrist drop" due to paralysis of the extensor muscles of the wrist. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve: It arises from the brachial plexus and passes posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus (the "funny bone").

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies many of the small muscles of the hand and some flexors in the forearm.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the medial (ulnar) one and a half fingers and the corresponding area of the palm and dorsum.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: "Claw hand" deformity due to loss of function in the ulnar half of the hand. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly associated with the condition shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pitting of nails

 

The given scenario suggests alopecia areata in which geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of nail is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

Alopecia areata:

 

  • Alopecia areata is a chronic Autoimmune disease that causes non scaring patches of hair loss.
  • It is a T cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed individuals. Pigmented hair is more frequently affected in alopecia areata.
  • Grey hair in older patients often includes both white and coloured hair. Only coloured hair will be impacted by the disease if it advances quickly, sparing white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair colour that is called going white overnight.

 

The following image sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nail changes are common in alopecia areata, with nail pitting being the most frequent finding.
  • Nail pitting appears as small depressions on the nail surface.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.28-33

choices.text: Transcervical resection of septum

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcervical resection of septum

 

Explanation:

 

  • Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.
  • The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of Cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the obstetric outcomes.

 

 

Other Options

 

Metroplasty is a type of unification procedures in mullerian anomalies

 

Option A. Jones metroplasty and Option C. Tompkins metroplasty are for septate uterus but are not preferred now. As now the treatment of choice is hysteroscopic resection of the septa.

 

Option B. Strassman metroplasty: Strassman metroplasty is for bicornuate uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the best corrective procedure for a septate uterus to improve obstetric outcomes, as it does not scar the uterus and allows for future vaginal deliveries.

 

Ref: Page no 659, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of the Demographic cycle in the correct chronological sequence: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Low stationary
  2. High stationary
  3. Declining
  4. Early expanding
  5. Late expanding
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 2 4 5 1 3

 

The Demographic Transition Model describes the stages a country goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. The stages of the demographic cycle in correct chronological order are:

 

2. High Stationary : This is the first stage characterized by high birth and high death rates, leading to a stable population. It reflects pre-industrial societies with limited medical care and poor living conditions.

 

4. Early Expanding: In this stage, death rates start to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition, while birth rates remain high, resulting in rapid population growth.

 

5. Late Expanding : Birth rates begin to fall as societies become more urbanized and access to contraception improves, but the population continues to grow, albeit at a slower rate.

 

1. Low Stationary : Both birth and death rates are low, stabilizing the population size. This stage reflects advanced economies with high living standards and access to family planning.

 

3. Declining : In the final stage, the birth rate falls below the death rate, leading to a declining population. This stage is seen in highly developed countries with aging populations and very low fertility rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the demographic cycle stages is: High Stationary, Early Expanding, Late Expanding, Low Stationary, and Declining.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis

 

The histopathological picture of the caseating granuloma, eosinophilic necrotic debris known as caseation, bordered by collections of epithelioid cells, Langhan giant cells (horse shoe shape), and lymphocytes, as well as the clinical history, indicate tuberculosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES: Tuberculosis presents with chronic cough, fever, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leprosy: Skin lesions and nerve involvement with loss of sensation.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions, non-caseating granuloma with fibroblastic proliferation at the periphery.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Thickened capsule/ hyperplasia of capsule accompanied by fibrosis, perivascular inflammation, and infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis is characterized by caseating granulomas with eosinophilic necrotic debris, surrounded by epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes. This histopathological pattern, along with the clinical presentation of chronic cough and cervical lymphadenopathy, is indicative of tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed, which revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions. What will be the next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MR spectroscopy

 

MR spectroscopy is the next best step when multiple ring-enhancing lesions are observed in the basal parts of the brain, suggesting tuberculomas. MR spectroscopy helps differentiate tuberculomas from other similar conditions, like neurocysticercosis (NCC), by identifying a characteristic lipid-lactate peak. The presence of this peak strongly favors a diagnosis of tuberculosis rather than NCC, which typically does not show this peak. This approach is a non-invasive and specific method to further evaluate the lesions, aligning with standard clinical protocols.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CBNAAT of CSF: CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) of CSF is mainly used for confirming tuberculous meningitis rather than localized brain lesions such as tuberculomas. It is not useful in directly evaluating ring-enhancing lesions seen on MRI.

 

Option C. Biopsy: Biopsy is an invasive procedure and is usually not the first choice due to potential complications. It is reserved for cases where non-invasive methods fail to provide a definitive diagnosis.

 

Option D. SWI (Susceptibility-Weighted Imaging): SWI is used primarily for detecting bleeds, microhemorrhages, or diffuse axonal injuries. It does not contribute to the diagnosis of ring-enhancing lesions caused by infections like tuberculosis or neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal brain region on MRI suggests tuberculomas, and MR spectroscopy is the preferred next step to confirm the diagnosis by detecting a lipid-lactate peak.

questions.text: Arrange the stages of wound healing in the correct sequence: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, remodeling 

 

Wound healing is a complex and dynamic process involving a sequence of interrelated phases. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The correct sequence of wound healing stages is hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling, reflecting the orderly process of wound repair from clot formation to tissue regeneration and maturation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with erectile dysfunction and bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest. The patient reports a history of smoking and high blood pressure. Physical examination reveals reduced sensation in both legs and weak pulses in the feet. Identify the location of the lesion? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortoiliac bifurcation

 

  • Bilateral lower limb claudication, weak pulses, and erectile dysfunction are suggestive of Leriche’s syndrome.
  • Leriche’s syndrome is a rare form of peripheral arterial disease caused by the obstruction or narrowing of the abdominal aorta, specifically at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • This is the location where the abdominal aorta splits into the left and right common iliac arteries.
  • Leriche syndrome (or aortoiliac occlusive disease) results from a blockage at this bifurcation.
  • Patients with this condition experience claudication (pain in the buttocks and thighs), erectile dysfunction (because of reduced blood flow to the pelvis), and decreased pulses in the legs.
  • Given the combination of symptoms, this location is the most plausible for the lesion in the presented case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral popliteal arteries: Obstruction or narrowing of these arteries could cause pain in the calves or feet, especially after walking or exercise. It would not explain the symptoms of erectile dysfunction.

 

Option B. Bilateral internal iliac arteries: The internal iliac arteries supply various pelvic organs, including the prostate, bladder, and rectum. While occlusion of the internal iliac arteries might explain some of the pelvic symptoms like erectile dysfunction, it's not likely to cause bilateral leg pain and reduced sensation in both legs.

 

Option D. Bilateral femoral arteries: The femoral arteries supply blood to the thighs and lower legs. Obstruction in these arteries can cause pain in the thighs or calves during walking or exercise. However, this wouldn't typically result in erectile dysfunction.

 

  • Given the combination of erectile dysfunction, bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest, and the reduced pulses in the feet, the aortoiliac bifurcation (option C) is the most likely location of the lesion, consistent with Leriche syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leriche syndrome, also known as aortoiliac occlusive disease, involves obstruction at the aortoiliac bifurcation, leading to symptoms like claudication, erectile dysfunction, and decreased lower limb pulses.

questions.text: Identify the marked cell from the given histological image of cerebellum: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Purkinje cells

 

The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells.

 

 

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Purkinje cells are specialized neurons located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum.
  • They are flask-shaped cells arranged in a single layer with even spacing.
  • Each Purkinje cell has a dendrite that rises from its neck and enters the molecular layer, where it branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell descends, crosses the granular cell layer, and enters the white matter. These axons are the only efferent fibers of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons, which provide inhibitory feedback.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei, where it synapses with other neurons to modulate motor function.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to regulate cerebellar output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basket cells: These are inhibitory interneurons found in the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their axons give rise to basket-like formations that surround the soma and initial axon segment of the Purkinje cells.
  • They play a role in modulating the activity of Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Golgi cells: These are also inhibitory interneurons, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their dendrites extend into the molecular layer where they synapse with the parallel fibers of granule cells.
  • Golgi cells provide feedback inhibition to granule cells, modulating their output.

 

Option D. Granule cells:

 

  • These are the most numerous neurons in the brain, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • They are excitatory neurons that receive input from the cerebellar afferents through the mossy fibers.
  • Their axons ascend into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate and run parallel to the surface, forming the parallel fibers. These fibers synapse with the dendrites of the Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells are among the largest neurons in the brain, located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex. They have a large, flask-shaped soma from which extend many branching dendrites. The dendritic tree is oriented perpendicularly to the surface of the cerebellum, extending into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells pass into the white matter and are the only axons that leave the cerebellar cortex to synapse with cells in the cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with itchy lesions on the wrist and involvement of oral mucosa, and on examination, following findings were noted. What will be the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lichen Planus

 

The skin lesion in the preceding image features the distinctive purple, flat, polygonal papules of lichen planus.

 

Lichen planus:

 

  • The five characteristics of lichen planus lesions are 5Ps: purple polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), and papules.
  • Lichen planus has characteristics including cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped purple polygonal papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails.
  • Lichen planus producing Cicatrizing/Scarring alopecia

 

  • In almost 30–70% of cases with lichen planus, mucous membrane lesions develop. It primarily affects the anal and genital mucosa as well as the tongue and buccal mucosa.
  • Wickham's striae are distinctive white streaks that create a lacework in the buccal mucosa.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lichen nitidus

 

  • Features: Lichen nitidus presents as tiny, flesh-coloured, shiny papules, primarily on the abdomen, chest, forearms, and genitals. It doesn't usually involve the oral mucosa.
  • Why it doesn't match: The primary presentation doesn't involve oral mucosa, and the typical presentation is different from the described symptoms.

 

Option C. Psoriasis

 

  • Features: Psoriasis often presents with sharply demarcated, erythematous, scaly plaques. Common locations include the knees, elbows, and scalp. Nail changes (like pitting) can be observed. The oral mucosa is rarely involved.
  • Why it doesn't match: While psoriasis can affect various parts of the body, involvement of the oral mucosa is uncommon. The described presentation fits lichen planus better.

 

Option D. Chicken pox

 

  • Features: Chicken pox is caused by the varicella-zoster virus and presents as an itchy rash that evolves into fluid-filled vesicles. The lesions progress to pustules and then crust over. It starts on the face and trunk and spreads outward. Oral lesions can be present but are usually ulcers.
  • Why it doesn't match: The progression and appearance of chicken pox lesions differ from the described presentation. Also, chicken pox usually has a systemic presentation with fever and malaise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lichen planus is recognized as the characteristic pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques, often with Wickham's striae, and the presence of lacy white lesions on the oral mucosa.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 31.24, 34.39, 35.1, 37.1, 37.4, 37.6

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple painful blisters on the trunk as shown in the image. Identify the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Herpes zoster

 

The above image shows multiple painful blisters on the trunk along dermatome which is suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

 

  • It is a human herpes virus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

• Painful zoster infections in adults

• Facial zoster at any age

• Immunocompromised

 

Complication of zoster:

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chicken pox (Varicella)

 

  • Features: Caused by the primary infection with varicella-zoster virus. It generally presents as an itchy, diffuse vesicular rash that starts on the face and trunk before spreading to the extremities. The rash evolves through stages, with papules, vesicles, pustules, and crusts present simultaneously.
  • Why it doesn't match: While chickenpox can produce blisters on the trunk, they are typically itchy rather than painful and appear in multiple stages of healing rather than uniformly as blisters. Also, chickenpox tends to start on the face and spread, not solely localized to the trunk.

 

Option C. Measles

 

  • Features: Caused by the measles virus, it presents with a high fever, malaise, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by a characteristic maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads downward. Koplik spots (white spots) on the buccal mucosa are a pathognomonic sign.
  • Why it doesn't match: Measles produces a maculopapular rash, not blisters. The systemic symptoms and the pattern of rash spread also don't align with the description.

 

Option D. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)

 

  • Features: It's a primary immunodeficiency disorder where there is a defect in both T and B cell immune responses. Infants with SCID present with recurrent infections, failure to thrive, and chronic diarrhoea. They are vulnerable to opportunistic infections.
  • Why it doesn't match: SCID itself does not cause blisters. Patients with SCID are susceptible to numerous infections due to their compromised immune system, but the mere presence of blisters would not immediately point to SCID without other accompanying symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes zoster is identified as painful, unilateral vesicular lesions within a dermatomal distribution on the patient's trunk.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Page no 106

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower limb wound as shown. The wound had healthy granulation tissue. What will be used as a cover? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Split thickness skin graft

 

The correct answer is Split thickness skin graft (STSG). STSG is the preferred choice for covering a large, healing wound with healthy granulation tissue, such as a burn or degloving injury. It involves taking a thin layer of skin from a donor site and applying it to the wound. This type of graft covers large areas and is effective in promoting wound healing with adequate tissue coverage while maintaining flexibility. It is generally used on body areas where cosmesis is less of a priority compared to the face, which would require a full thickness graft.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Full thickness skin graft: This graft involves both the epidermis and the entire dermis and is typically used for areas requiring greater cosmetic outcomes, such as the face. It is not generally used for large wounds with healthy granulation tissue, as STSG would suffice and cover larger areas with a better healing outcome.

 

Option C.  VAC dressing: Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing is used for non-healing or chronic wounds that require additional stimulation for granulation tissue formation and wound contraction. It is not needed when the wound already has healthy granulation tissue and is progressing well in healing.

 

Option D.  Flap: A flap is used when there is a need for bulk tissue to cover a deep or complex wound that involves structures like bone, tendons, or joints. Since the wound described has healthy granulation tissue and is not deep, a flap is unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Split thickness skin grafts are the best choice for covering large, healthy granulating wounds, particularly in areas where cosmesis is not the primary concern.

choices.text: Segment la is due to residual urine
Segment II is due to Laplace law
Micturition fails to happen in segment II
The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Segment II is due to Laplace Law

 

Explanation:

 

The true statement regarding the given cystometrogram is that segment lb is due to Laplace law.

 

The law of Laplace correlates volume and wall tension, is applicable to urine storage.

 

According to Law of Laplace, the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R.

 

As the bladder gets filled, the radius increases along with the tension, hence there is a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full, which explains the flatness of the graph in segment II

 

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.

 

Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

 

 

  1. Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase): This phase represents the storage phase of bladder function.
  2. Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase): In this phase, the intravesical pressure increases more rapidly as the bladder volume reaches a certain threshold. The detrusor muscle, which contracts to initiate bladder emptying, starts to generate increased pressure as the bladder approaches its capacity. This phase represents the transition from storage to voiding phase.
  3. Voiding Phase (or Micturition Phase): In the voiding phase, the intravesical pressure rises to its highest level as the detrusor muscle contracts forcefully to empty the bladder. The pressure exceeds the urethral resistance, resulting in urine expulsion. This phase is associated with the sensation of needing to urinate and the act of micturition (urination).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Segment Ia is due to residual urine: Incorrect. Segment I, particularly the initial part of the curve, typically represents the early filling phase of the bladder, not necessarily residual urine.

 

Option C. Micturition fails to happen in segment II: Incorrect. Segment II represents the continuation of the filling phase; micturition (urination) does not occur here because it typically begins when the bladder reaches its threshold capacity and the detrusor muscle contracts, which would be represented later in the graph.

 

Option D. The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred: Incorrect. The dotted line likely indicates phase transitions within the bladder's filling and voiding cycle, not necessarily the occurrence of micturition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segment II of a cystometrogram, characterized by Laplace's Law, illustrates how the bladder can accommodate increasing volumes of urine with minimal increase in pressure, showcasing the bladder's compliance during the urine storage phase. This is crucial for diagnosing and managing conditions related to bladder storage and voiding dysfunction.

questions.text: Which among the following according to the latest guidelines is NOT an indication to IE prophylaxis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atrial Septal Defect

 

According to the latest guidelines, there are specific indications for infective endocarditis (IE) prophylaxis to prevent infection in high-risk patients. These indications include:

 

  1. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Patients with a history of infective endocarditis are at increased risk for recurrence and hence, are recommended for prophylaxis.
  2. Prosthetic Valves: Patients with prosthetic heart valves, especially mechanical valves, are susceptible to infections and require prophylaxis.
  3. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Those who have undergone cardiac transplant and have developed valvulopathy are also indicated for IE prophylaxis.
  4. Congenital Heart Disease: This includes any unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, repaired congenital heart disease with prosthetic material for the first six months post-repair, or repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects.

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not listed among these high-risk conditions. ASD, especially without significant gradient across the atria or significant shunting, has a very low risk of causing infective endocarditis. Therefore, ASD does not fit into the current guidelines for IE prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Prior infective endocarditis significantly increases the risk of recurrent infection, thus requiring IE prophylaxis as per the guidelines.

 

Option C. Unrepaired Cyanotic Congenital Heart Disease: Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease is a high-risk condition for infective endocarditis, necessitating prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Patients who have undergone a cardiac transplant and have valvulopathy are at increased risk for infection and are indicated for IE prophylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not an indication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis according to the latest guidelines, whereas prior infective endocarditis, prosthetic valves, cardiac transplant with valvulopathy, and certain congenital heart diseases are key indications.

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Reduced serum iron level

2.Reduced transferrin saturation

3.Increased total iron binding capacity

4.Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4


Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is characterized by reduced ferritin, which is the one of the first indicators of IDA, ferritin indicates the iron stores in the body. Serum iron levels will drop after ferritin levels decrease. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) will increase. Transferrin saturation, a measure of iron and TIBC, will reduce. Transferrin saturation is less than 18%, but less than 20% indicates iron deficiency anemia.

 

  1. Reduced serum iron level: Low iron levels in the blood.
  2. Reduced transferrin saturation: Less iron available for transport.
  3. Increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC): The body produces more transferrin to capture iron.
  4. Reduced ferritin level: Indicates low iron stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia involves reduced serum iron, reduced transferrin saturation, increased TIBC, and reduced ferritin levels

choices.text: Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3

questions.text: Bindi Leukoderma is caused by which chemical? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP)

 

Bindi leukoderma is caused by para tertiary butylphenol (PTBP) present in adhesive sticker Bindi.

 

  • This is called contact leukoderma or chemical leukoderma in which the chemical increases sensitivity and induces apoptosis of the melanocytes in the area of contact.
  • There is also evidence that azo dyes, by virtue of structural similarity to tyrosine, can directly inhibit methanogenesis by competing with that amino acid for binding with tyrosinase enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. p-phenylenediamine (PPD): Commonly found in hair dyes and can cause allergic reactions and leukoderma but is not the cause of Bindi leukoderma.

 

Option C. Mono-benzyl ether of Hydroquinone (MBEH): Used in rubber and other synthetic materials to cause depigmentation but not in bindi adhesives.

 

Option D. Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3: Azo dyes used in Alta dye, associated with chemical leukoderma but not specifically with bindi leukoderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP), which is a chemical present in high concentrations in the glue of sticker bindis and is known to cause leukoderma through its melanocytotoxic properties.

 

Common chemicals in Indian setup which can Cause chemical leukoderma are:

 

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 128 page no 128.74

Online source: https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/2965911

Question Level – Intermediate 

Question Id-7458 Unique Key-Q8927704

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital within 3 hours of the onset of chest pain. ECG revealed ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion. She could be best managed by? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin with heparin

 

The description of diffuse symmetric TWI without ST elevations is consistent with NSTEMI which is characterized by subtotal platelet-rich thrombosis + distal phasic embolization. NSTEMI treated with DAPT+LMWH followed by CAG for risk stratification

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCI is treatment of choice for STEMI.

 

Option B. Arrhythmia prophylaxis is not the definitive best management strategy

 

Option C. Thrombolysis/Fibrinolytics have no role in the management of NSTEMI

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/ACS/Chap 277

questions.text:
Oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of which of the following cranial nerves? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. III

2. IV

3. VI

4. VIII

5. VII
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 4

 

The oculocephalic reflex, also known as the doll's eye reflex, is a brainstem reflex useful test for evaluating the function of cranial nerves III, VI, and VIII to determine brainstem function and assess brain death.

 

  • It is elicited by the examiner rapidly rotating the patient's head and observing the resulting eye movements. The test is performed in both lateral directions, as well as during flexion and extension of the neck. 
  • The oculomotor (III) nerve receives input from the vestibular (VIII) and abducens (VI) nerves, which relay signals to the brainstem nuclei responsible for generating conjugate eye movements. 
  • In a normal reflex, the eyes move in the opposite direction of head movement to maintain their orientation in space.

 

A negative reflex can indicate cranial nerve palsies or brainstem damage if the eyes do not move or move in the same direction as head movement. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of cranial nerves III (oculomotor), VI (abducens), and VIII (vestibulocochlear), which are crucial for coordinated eye movements in response to head motion.

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Countertransference

 

Countertransference refers to the therapist's emotional reactions, both conscious and unconscious, towards a patient, often influenced by the therapist's own past.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transference: Transference is when the patient unconsciously redirects feelings experienced in an earlier relationship to the therapist.

 

Option C. Dissociation: Dissociation is a disconnection and lack of continuity between thoughts, memories, surroundings, actions, and identity.

 

Option D. Dissociation: Preoccupation is being absorbed in thought, typically about something particular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Transference refers to the redirection of a patient's feelings and attitudes from past experiences or individuals onto the therapist, typically operating on an unconscious level. Countertransference represents the therapist's emotional reactions to a patient, both conscious and unconscious. These reactions may be influenced by the therapist's own personal history, unresolved conflicts, or reactions to the patient's transference.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1069

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

 

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cutdown procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.
  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cutdown procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial Peroneal Nerve: This nerve originates from the common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve). It runs in the lateral compartment of the leg.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies sensation to the dorsum (top) of the foot and a small area over the lateral aspect of the lower leg.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution and potential weakness in eversion of the foot.

 

Option C. Femoral Nerve: Arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4).

 

  • Motor Functions: It supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh which are primarily responsible for hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory Distribution: Over the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg (via the saphenous nerve, its branch).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in hip flexion and knee extension along with sensory loss over its distribution.

 

Option D. Sural Nerve: This nerve is formed by branches from both the tibial and common peroneal nerves. It runs along the posterior and then lateral side of the calf.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies the posterolateral aspect of the leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crown rump length

 

Explanation:

 

Crown rump length is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Biparietal diameter, B. Head circumference and D. Abdominal circumference are parameters useful in second trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crown rump length is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 84

choices.text: Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations

questions.text: What are the potential observations that could be observed in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of sensation over foot

 

In this case, the patient is likely to have a neuropathic/trophic ulcer, which is characterized by a lack of sensation over the foot due to peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are painless and have punched-out margins with the presence of calluses. The ulcer is located on the plantar surface of the foot (weight bearing area). The other options, such as decreased pulsations in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries, positive Trendelenburg sign, and pain on compression of calf, are not likely to be seen in this patient with a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Loss of sensation over the foot can lead to neuropathic/trophic ulcers as seen above. This is usually seen in neuropathies like Diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations: Decreased or absent posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulsations are indicative of vascular compromise or reduced blood flow to the lower extremity. This can lead to ischemic ulcers which are seen at tips of toes, web spaces, dorsum of foot etc. The image does not suggest an ischemic ulcer.

 

Option C. Positive Trendelenberg test: This is seen in varicose veins with saphenofemoral incompetence, and may have varicose ulcers above medial malleolus (Gaiter’s area). The image is not a case of varicose ulcer.

 

Option D. Pain on compression of calf: Pain on compression of the calf may indicate a potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to calf pain and swelling and venous ulcers. The image is not a case of DVT with venous ulcer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of sensation over the foot is a potential observation that could be observed in a patient with neuropathic/trophic ulcers.

questions.text: A patient presents with a mobile, warm to touch nodule in the neck. On the anaerobic culture of the biopsy material from this swelling, it showed colonies as shown in the image which had gram-positive branching rods on staining. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillin

 

The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth suggestive of actinomycete infection of cervicofacial region also called as Lumpy jaw.

 

Culture characteristics - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth.

 

Gram-positive filamentous branching rods. Non-motile, non-sporing and non-acid-fast. Clumps of the organisms can be seen as yellowish ‘sulphur granules’ in pus discharging from sinus tracts, or the granules can be squeezed out of the lesions.

 

Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin such as amoxicillin are now popular. Clindamycin and erythromycin are effective in patients with penicillin allergy. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: Effective for certain infections but not the first-line treatment for actinomycete infections.

 

Option B. Cotrimoxazole: Not typically used for actinomycete infections.

 

Option D. Surgical drainage: May be required as an adjunct to antibiotic therapy in chronic cases, but it is not the primary treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penicillin is the drug of choice for treating actinomycete infections, particularly in cervicofacial cases presenting with nodules and characteristic colonies. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is necessary, and surgical intervention may be required for chronic lesions.

questions.text: The given condition is caused by which drug? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bleomycin

 

  • The given image shows flagellate dermatitis. It is caused by bleomycin.
  • Flagellate dermatoses are infrequent types of figurate dermatoses characterized by parallel lines or curves resembling whiplash marks.
  • Bleomycin, a polypeptide chemotherapeutic agent, primarily affects the respiratory and cutaneous systems, likely due to the absence of the inactivating enzyme hydrolase in these tissues.

 

 

  • It manifests as widespread, itchy, flagellate, erythematous plaques on the trunk and extremities within hours to months after bleomycin administration.
  • Flagellate hyperpigmentation may persist even after the rash has resolved.
  • While there is no specific treatment for this condition, avoiding bleomycin can lead to clearance of the symptoms over several months to years.
  • However, re-exposure to the drug might trigger a more severe reaction.
  • Bleomycin is also associated with development of pulmonary fibrosis.
  • Peplomycin, a bleomycin derivative with reduced pulmonary toxicity, is utilized in the treatment of prostatic carcinoma and lymphomas. Nevertheless, it has been associated with flagellate erythema through mechanisms like those of bleomycin.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Bleomycin, on the other hand, can cause skin side effects like flagellate erythema, which appears as streaky red or hyperpigmented lines on the skin, resembling the appearance in the image provided. This particular side effect is a hallmark of Bleomycin toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students and residents, it is crucial to identify bleomycin as the chemotherapeutic agent that can cause flagellate hyperpigmentation, a dermatological side effect not commonly associated with actinomycin, mitomycin C, or doxorubicin.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 4 & 120, Page no 4.12 & 120.8

Goodman & Gillman’s The pharmacological basis of therapeutics 13th edition Page no 1193

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3702947/

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/share/F7KSRDKWUJX3W2GZTEAC?target=10.1002/ski2.92

questions.text: A 30-year-old male travels frequently and has food during his travels. He presents to PHC OPD with abdominal pain, fever for 4 days. He has bradycardia too. Test for confirmation of diagnosis: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Blood culture

 

The clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of enteric fever (typhoid), characterized by abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia. The appropriate diagnostic test depends on the stage of the illness:

 

Blood culture is the test of choice from the first week of illness onwards. It remains the most reliable test in the initial stages (within the first week of symptoms) to confirm typhoid fever. This test directly detects the presence of Salmonella bacteria in the blood, making it the most accurate diagnostic method during early illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Widal test: This serological test detects antibodies against Salmonella and is typically used from the second week of illness onwards. It is not the preferred test during the first week as antibodies may not yet be present in detectable quantities.

 

Option C. Stool culture: This is used from the third week of illness onwards and detects Salmonella in the gastrointestinal tract. It is not suitable for early diagnosis as it becomes positive later in the disease course.

 

Option D. Urine culture: This is used from the fourth week of illness onwards. It detects Salmonella excreted in the urine, but like stool culture, it is useful later in the course of the disease and not for initial diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For typhoid fever diagnosis in the first week of illness, blood culture is the most appropriate and reliable test.

 

Mnemonic – BASU

 

Blood culture – 1st week onwards

Antibody test (Widal) – 2nd week onwards

Stool culture – 3rd week onwards

Urine culture – 4th week onwards

choices.text: LAP score
FISH and PCR

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of fatigue persisting for the past year, accompanied by massive splenomegaly. A comprehensive blood workup has been performed, revealing several notable findings. The patient exhibits anemia and a significantly elevated total leukocyte count of 50,000/microL. Further analysis of the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of neutrophils (60%), basophils (4%), eosinophils, and myoblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Additionally, the myeloid to erythroid ratio is found to be 18:1. Which investigation would be the most sensitive for further evaluation in this case: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FISH and PCR

 

The clinical picture of fatigue, splenomegaly, and peripheral blood smear findings suggest chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests are used to detect the BCR-ABL gene, which is specific for CML.

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative disorder that most commonly affects people in their fifth to sixth decade of life. A reciprocal (9;22) (g34;g11) translocation results in the creation of the chimeric BC-ABL gene (Philadelphia chromosome). This BCR-ABL gene differentiates ML from other myeloproliferative disorders and can be detected using fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) .

 

Clinical characteristics:

 

Mild to moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis.

 

Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

 

Peripheral blood:

 

  • Severe leukocytosis with a leukocyte count that frequently exceeds 100,000 cells/mm, primarily composed of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Moderate normocytic normochromic anemia - Rising basophilia indicates impending blastic transformation.
  • The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • Blastic phase or blast crisis in CML satisfies the definition of acute leukemia by having more than 20% blood or marrow blasts.
  • Anemia of moderate severity - A rising basophilia is indicative of impending blastic transformation. - The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • A blast phase or blast crisis in CML meets the definition of acute leukemia by having blood or marrow blasts of more than 20%.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunophenotyping: Used for the diagnosis of various hematologic malignancies, particularly lymphoid neoplasms. It is less specific for CML.

 

Option  B. LAP score (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase): The LAP score is typically low in CML, but this test is less specific and has largely been replaced by molecular diagnostic techniques like FISH and PCR.

 

Option D. Flow cytometry: Useful for identifying and classifying hematologic malignancies based on cell surface markers but is not the most specific test for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are the most sensitive investigations for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the hallmark of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). These tests are crucial for accurate diagnosis and monitoring of CML.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

The correct match for Wullstein’s classification is a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

  1. Type II – 2. graft placed over the incus
  2. Type III – 4. columella tympanoplasty
  3. Type IV – 3. Cavum minor
  4. Type V – 1. Fenestration tympanoplasty

 

  1. Type II (Ossiculoplasty): Malleus partially eroded; ossicular chain reconstruction involves placing a graft over the incus.
  2. Type III (Columella Effect): Malleus and incus eroded; new TM coupled to the stapes head, referred to as columella tympanoplasty.
  3. Type IV (Cavum Minor): Stapedial head also eroded; new TM and new ossicular coupling to the stapes footplate.
  4. Type V (Fenestration Operation): Creating a fenestra and coupling the ossicular chain to the scala vestibuli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty provides a systematic approach to different types of middle ear reconstructions based on the extent of ossicular damage and required surgical repair.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of type 2 diabetes is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. SGLT2 inhibitors work by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine. This mechanism of action results in a higher concentration of glucose in the urinary tract, which can promote bacterial growth and lead to an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: This drug is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity but is not associated with an increased risk of UTIs. Instead, it can cause side effects such as fluid retention, weight gain, and an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: This is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor that increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels in the bloodstream. It is associated with risks such as pancreatitis and gastrointestinal disturbances but not with an increased risk of UTIs.

 

Option D. Metformin: This is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. Common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., diarrhea) and vitamin B12 deficiency, but it does not increase the risk of UTIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This highlights the importance of monitoring for UTIs in patients prescribed this medication.

questions.text: Addison's disease can present with symptoms similar to which of the following disorders? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depression

 

Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, is a condition where the adrenal glands do not produce sufficient steroid hormones, specifically cortisol and aldosterone. Symptoms of Addison's disease include fatigue, muscle weakness, weight loss, low blood pressure, and skin hyperpigmentation. These symptoms, especially fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight loss, can overlap with the symptoms of depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized anxiety disorder primarily involves excessive, uncontrollable worry about everyday events. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Option C. Bipolar disorder is characterized by mood episodes, including mania (or hypomania) and depression. It may be seen in Addison’s disease, but it is rare.

 

Option D. Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent unexpected panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Addison's disease is due to hypofunctioning of the adrenocortical system. It can mimic depression due to overlapping symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and low mood. It is essential to consider medical conditions that can present similarly to psychiatric disorders to ensure accurate diagnosis and treatment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 682.
